#Text=Chiba ( prefecture )
#Text=Chiba Prefecture
#Text=( 千葉県 Chiba-Ken ) is located directly east of Tokyo , and bordered by Ibaraki Prefecture to the north .
#Text=A large part of the prefecture is made up of the Bōsō Peninsula ( 房総半島 Bōsō-hantō ) , which shields Tokyo bay from the Pacific Ocean .

#Text=Much of the western/northwestern part of Chiba is relatively uninspired urbanity and bedtowns for Tokyo , but once you get past the city and watch the sharp descent into rural countryside of sprawling rice fields , rolling hills , and striking coastlines , you will realize why Chiba has been variously called " Edo 's Breadbasket " , " Japan 's Golf Mecca " , and " Tokyo 's Secret Backyard " .

column1: #Text=The area is relatively poorly known , even among Japanese people , but is nonetheless a great place to get away from Tokyo and explore a Japan a bit off the beaten track .
#Text=Cities
#Text=- eponymous capital of the prefecture , which does n't bear much resemblance to William Gibson 's depictions but has a few points of interest .
#Text=- suburban city
#Text=- a small city immediately across the Edo River from Tokyo .
#Text=- suburban shopping haven .
#Text=- home of famous Katori-Jinju Shrine , the historic streets of Sawara , and the bi-annual Sawara Matsuri festival .
#Text=- old fishing town on the southwestern pacific Boso ( " Sotobo " ) coast .
#Text=Famous for its Katsuura Hinamatsuri Doll Festival and katsuo tuna catch .
#Text=- largest city on the interior Boso ( " Uchibo " ) coast , and connected by the Tokyo Bay Aqualine bridge-tunnel to Kawasaki in Kanagawa .
#Text=- city in northwestern Chiba , bordering Edo River and Tokyo .
#Text=Residence of the Tokugawa Akitake , the beloved brother of Japan 's last shogun .
#Text=- a small city rich in historical treasures that is often overshadowed by its huge airport .
#Text=Home to Narita-san Shinshouji Temple and Boso-no-Mura .
#Text=- bedroom city for Tokyo and Chiba , home to the Kikkoman soy sauce empire .
#Text=- small town bordering Katsuura on the southwest Boso ( " Sotobo " ) coast .
#Text=- small town on the Pacific coast famous for strawberries and surfing .
#Text=- small city next to Chiba City that is famous for its production of peanuts .
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=- the tip at the South of Chiba .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Many parts of Chiba can be visited on a day trip from Tokyo .
#Text=The Pacific coast is dotted with many traditional fishing villages , and young surfers from Tokyo are attracted by the waves .
#Text=The inner coast is less picturesque , but the cliffs of Nokogiriyama are a popular tourist attraction .
#Text=Get in
#Text=While JR trains run the entire coast of Chiba , the inner coast is just a 30-minute ferry ride from Kurihama , south of Yokohama .
#Text=1997 saw the completion of the Tokyo Wan Aqua Line bridge and tunnel , which burrows under and rises across Tokyo Bay between Kisarazu ( Chiba prefecture ) and Kawasaki ( on the Tokyo side ) .
#Text=The tunnel is not economical at ¥ 4000 for a passenger car , unless you have an ETC card which brings the price down to 1500 yen .
#Text=You can take highway buses through the tunnel and over the bridge from Tokyo Station , Shinagawa , Haneda Airport , Kawasaki and Yokohama stations for up to ¥ 1500 one way to Kisarazu .
#Text=By train
#Text=The center of the JR network in Chiba is , unsurprisingly , JR Chiba Station .
#Text=But be careful when taking trains to the Boso Peninsula , as there are two different ways trains can get to Awa-Kamogawa , the final stop .

#Text=The Uchibō Line ( 内房線 ) , or " Inner Boso Line " , follows the western coast ( Tokyo Bay side ) through Kisarazu , while the Sotobō or " Outer Boso " Line ( 外房線 ) cuts across the peninsula and then goes down the east coast ( Pacific Ocean side ) via Katsuura .
#Text=Additionally , trains to Choshi can turn north at Sakura to go via Narita ( the Narita Line ) , or go south via Naruto along the Sobu Main Line .
#Text=To summarize all that , here are the platforms to take at Chiba station :
#Text=See
#Text=Nokogiriyama
#Text=( 鋸山 ) .
#Text=Meaning " sawtooth mountain " , Nokogiriyama is a group of Buddhist temples cut into sheer cliffs .

#Text=A rope-way gondola will take you up to the top , and on a clear day you 'll have a spectacular 180-degree panorama spanning Chiba , Tokyo , and Yokohama to the north , Mount Fuji to the west , and Izu Oshima and Niijima to the south .
#Text=Even on a so-so day , Yokosuka should be visible across Tokyo Bay .
#Text=The most popular vantage point is Jigoku-nozoki ( 地獄覗き , " peering into hell " ) a small rock platform which sticks out over cliff .
#Text=In the other direction you can see the low mountains of the interior Boso peninsula .
#Text=From the peak , paths descend inland through the woods down to Nihonji ( 日本寺 ) .
#Text=The temple , built in 725 C.E. , has a stone buddha statue that , at a total height of 31.05 meters , is in fact one of the largest buddha statues in Japan .
#Text=From the Tokyo area , you can get to Nogokiriyama via the Tokyo Bay ferry from Kurihama ( south of Yokohama ) for 1000 yen .
#Text=There are buses from the JR and Keikyu stations to the Tokyo-Wan Ferry Terminal , or you can walk ( 20 minutes ) .
#Text=On the Chiba side , Hamakanaya station is at the foot of the mountain and the ferry terminal is about 500m further away .

#Text=Most people take the ropeway ( 500 yen one-way , 930 yen two-ways ) but good hikers should hike through the nice forest , 50 minutes before reaching the cliff where you can see the caves from below , very impressive .
#Text=You might even spot a few old excavation machines .

#Text=It should be taken into consideration that if you choose to descend the entire mountain on foot there is a long walk to the nearest rail station , the Hota JR station , with very infrequent service .
#Text=If you have a car , you can take the non-free road that leads to the same place as the rope-way , but starts from further south .
#Text=The entire area at the top of the rocks is a temple with a 600 yen entry fee .
#Text=The ropeway station has a small free museum explaining rock excavation .
#Text=ropeway return ticket + temple : ¥ 1530 .
#Text=Kujukuri-hama
#Text=( 九十九里浜 ) .
#Text=This beach is , for many travelers , their first glimpse of Japan : it 's the long coastline you see from the plane coming in over the Pacific into Narita .
#Text=The name means " 99-ri coast " , where a " ri " is an old unit of length equal to about 654 meters .
#Text=The coast is in fact around 60km in length .
#Text=There are numerous small towns along the coast , from Iioka on the north to Ichinomiya on the south .
#Text=The lower Boso peninsula has several artificial attractions that are popular for family excursions but probably of limited appeal to other travelers :
#Text=Kamogawa Sea World
#Text=( 鴨川シーワールド ) .
#Text=Marine park
#Text=Mother Farm
#Text=( マザー牧場 ) .
#Text=A farm where kids can pet cows , alpacas and other animals .
#Text=At the pig race , kids direct their pig to the finish line as fast as possible .
#Text=Also .
#Text=Free on rainy days , but not everything is free inside .
#Text=ticket purchased locally/in advance in a combini : adults ¥1500/¥ 1350 ; kids : ¥800/¥ 700 .
#Text=Tokyo German Village
#Text=( 東京ドイツ村 ) .
#Text=Reconstructed half-timbered houses and bratwurst meals .
#Text=Because why not .
#Text=Also , do n't miss :
#Text=Narita Shinshouji Temple and surrounding traditional shopping streets
#Text=National Museum of Japanese History in Sakura
#Text=Tokyo Disney Resort
